pullRequest.body:
This PR follows the approach of #19065 to solve painful definitional equalities problems by forbidding the identification of `A ‚ü∂ B` and `A ‚Üí‚Çó[R] B`. These are not equal reducibly, so tactics get confused if one is replaced by the other.

There seem to be a few regressions caused by defeq abuse that we were able to get away with previously, but some subtle elaboration differences made it evident. Otherwise the cost is inserting many `.hom`s and `asHom`s.

A few steps that might clean up the diff, but would be too much work to incorporate in this PR:
 * Make the `ext` tactic pick up `TensorProduct.ext` again.
 * Replace the defeq abuse between `(restrictScalars f).obj M` and `M` with explicit maps going back and forth.

Overall quite a few proofs could be cleaned up at the cost of more bookkeeping.

---

- [ ] depends on: #19705

GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

<details><summary>Decrease in tech debt: (relative, absolute) = (5.49, 0.03)</summary>

|Current number|Change|Type|
|-:|:-:|:-|
|4981|-30|porting notes|
|202|-2|disabled simpNF lints|
|1498|-24|erw|

Current commit [f8f8363b30](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/f8f8363b30bf3426fabad9c002a2f722daafa3f8)
Reference commit [a38db992d0](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/a38db992d088e602ba99cdf94f77435bf23e9b8e)

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Overall this looks very good and a lot of proofs got cleaner! Did you run your magic `erw -> rw` tool? I could imagine there is some potential.

I hope you don't mind that I pushed some small changes to get rid of some more `erw`s.

I tried to add a test file similar to the one for `AlgebraCat`, but I am running into this:
```
import Mathlib
open CategoryTheory ModuleCat
variable (R : Type u) [CommRing R]

/-
ambiguous, possible interpretations 
  ‚Üüf : of R X ‚ü∂ of R Y
  
  ‚Üæ‚áëf : X ‚ü∂ Y
-/
example {X Y : Type v} [AddCommGroup X] [Module R X] [AddCommGroup Y] [Module R Y] (f : X ‚Üí‚Çó[R] Y)
    (x : X) : (asHom f) x = f x := by simp
```
Do you understand this?

I think the testcase fails because there is also the definition [`CategoryTheory.asHom`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/CategoryTheory/Types.html#CategoryTheory.asHom) which is `ModuleCat.asHom` but for the category of types. So we either apply `ModuleCat.asHom` and then coerce back to a function, or we coerce `f` to a function, apply `CategoryTheory.asHom` to make it a morphism, and then coerce it back to a plain function. And since both of the end results have the same types and applicability, Lean can't choose and throws an error.

> I think the testcase fails because there is also the definition [`CategoryTheory.asHom`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/CategoryTheory/Types.html#CategoryTheory.asHom) which is `ModuleCat.asHom` but for the category of types. So we either apply `ModuleCat.asHom` and then coerce back to a function, or we coerce `f` to a function, apply `CategoryTheory.asHom` to make it a morphism, and then coerce it back to a plain function. And since both of the end results have the same types and applicability, Lean can't choose and throws an error.

Ah, silly me, I didn't think of `CategoryTheory.asHom` and was not aware of the notation. Replacing the `asHom` with `ModuleCat.asHom` makes everything work.
I put the tests in 554ba6315ef, if you like them feel free to cherry-pick (or tell me to push it here).
Thank you! Feel free to push your commit directly to this branch. :)

> Overall this looks very good and a lot of proofs got cleaner! Did you run your magic `erw -> rw` tool? I could imagine there is some potential.
> 
> I hope you don't mind that I pushed some small changes to get rid of some more `erw`s.

I did run it on an earlier version of the branch, let me see if anything got cleared up in the meantime.

(It should be as easy as merging the `try_this-erw` branch into the current branch, and then cherry-picking any of the warnings it produces.)
No free `erw` eliminations found on this branch, but I did find a few in other bits of Mathlib so time to make a little PR for that :D
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/698fc869-9376-4049-8627-f1c0e9b2896c) for commit 867bc8212c6d6651ab13f5153cb4748e2e73bd3d.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/bcf67c94-f0d0-45cd-bab5-2518ad8d3eff/to/698fc869-9376-4049-8627-f1c0e9b2896c) against commit 7f28d7f73f74b31f72449bb9eb240db3ca68fe38:
```diff
  Benchmark                                                    Metric         Change
  ==================================================================================
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Algebra                  instructions   227.7%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Basic                    instructions    45.8%
+ ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.ChangeOfRings            instructions   -28.9%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Differentials.Presheaf   instructions    14.3%
+ ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Presheaf                 instructions   -17.1%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Presheaf.ChangeOfRings   instructions    28.0%
+ ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Presheaf.Monoidal        instructions   -18.0%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Presheaf.Pushforward     instructions    18.2%
+ ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Presheaf.Sheafify        instructions   -12.5%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Sheaf.Colimits           instructions    61.2%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Homology.ShortComplex.ModuleCat             instructions    66.2%
- ~Mathlib.AlgebraicGeometry.Modules.Tilde                     instructions    25.4%
+ ~Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Monoidal.Internal.Module             instructions    -9.3%
- ~Mathlib.RepresentationTheory.Rep                            instructions    12.4%
```

Hmm, a very mixed result. The really big slowdowns were in files that had a lot of manual proofs replaced with automation, but still `Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Sheaf.Colimits` +61.2% with no changed lines is scary. Let me see if I can discover what is slow...

The +227% one can be safely ignored, its a 60L file with one proof. Why do we not get the nice summary with all the instruction increases starting from 10^9? Does this mean, all of the changes are below that threshold? If yes, I think everything is fine.

`Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Sheaf.Colimits` is also a one-proof file. If I can trust `set_option trace.profiler true` somewhat, then it looks like elaboration of that proof takes slightly less than `50%` longer, and kernel typechecking twice as long. But there is no obvious change in the steps taken to get there, just a bit of slowdown at every level...

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#19705~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ü§ñ). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/1807ed17-3561-4775-aac8-55b11db574ad) for commit f8f8363b30bf3426fabad9c002a2f722daafa3f8.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/376caf18-3015-4b16-80e7-6763a47746fd/to/1807ed17-3561-4775-aac8-55b11db574ad) against commit a38db992d088e602ba99cdf94f77435bf23e9b8e:
```diff
  Benchmark                                                    Metric         Change
  ==================================================================================
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Algebra                  instructions   227.1%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Basic                    instructions    46.7%
+ ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.ChangeOfRings            instructions   -30.3%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Differentials.Presheaf   instructions    15.2%
+ ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Presheaf                 instructions   -16.9%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Presheaf.ChangeOfRings   instructions    28.3%
+ ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Presheaf.Monoidal        instructions   -16.7%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Presheaf.Pushforward     instructions    19.1%
+ ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Presheaf.Sheafify        instructions   -13.4%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Sheaf.Colimits           instructions    61.8%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Homology.ShortComplex.ModuleCat             instructions    71.3%
- ~Mathlib.AlgebraicGeometry.Modules.Tilde                     instructions    24.1%
- ~Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Linear.Yoneda                        instructions    19.8%
+ ~Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Monoidal.Internal.Module             instructions    -9.2%
- ~Mathlib.RepresentationTheory.Rep                            instructions    12.1%
```
This instance causes downstream issues in `Mathlib/Algebra/Category/ModuleCat/Presheaf/Pushforward.lean:40`, where the synthesized instance does not equal the one obtained by unification.
Having to type-ascribe `asHom` suggests there is some defeq abuse going on.
The `@[simps]` lemma generated here has the wrong type, but if we type-ascript `asHom` to give it the right type, then the proofs in this definition breaks.
More signs of defeq abuse.
This should be defeq now to `asHom`. Can we safely replace it? (i.e. deprecated alias it)
This feels like there is some categorical definition already, but I couldn't find it (without searching very hard).
We should really fix the issue that makes `TensorProduct.ext'` not apply using the `ext` tactic...
Agreed, but a problem for another day :)
More defeq issues.
More defeq issues...
This suggests `colimit_no_zero_smul_divisor` is not phrased correctly.
Also some errors downstream of this that I haven't figured out.
This proof got uglier, not sure what the concrete cause is.
I tried a few things and it seems there was already a lot of defeq abuse that got exposed now.
This proof got a lot uglier, not sure what the concrete cause is.
Should probably be moved to `ModuleCat/Basic.lean`, if that has the right imports.
Is there a categorical name for this thing?
It seems to me like this should work for endomorphism monoids in any `bundled` category.
This is the major regression of this PR: we needed to specialize these results because there is no longer a good way to say for `ModuleCat` that all its homs are linear maps.
I think this should be called `ofHom` to align with the other concrete categories, but the diff of this PR is already large enough so I am fine with leaving this to a follow-up.

Yeah, I was very unsure which convention to follow: existing `ModuleCat.asHom` usage or consistency with the other categories. It's kind of funny that a couple months ago the deprecated alias was `ofHom` and now we want it to be exactly the opposite. :)
Here `V W : FGModuleCat R`, but I think this should take `V W : Type u` with `Module R V` etc.

```suggestion
@[simps]
def endMulEquiv : End M ‚âÉ* (M ‚Üí‚Çó[R] M) where
  toFun := ModuleCat.Hom.hom
```
maybe?
This makes me happy :)
What's going on here?
Ah I suppose this is related to the def-eq abuse you mention in the PR description concerning `ModuleCat.restrictScalars` right?

It's a bit more complicated but basically yes: we have that the codomain of `((toSheafify Œ± œÜ).app X).hom` would by default be inferred as some object which is only definitionally equal to `(ModuleCat.restrictScalars (Œ±.app X)).obj _))`. And these definitional equalities are `dsimp` lemmas so they do get applied before `toSheafify_app_apply` (which therefore would never get applied since it looks like it has the wrong type).

One idea I just had: maybe specify `no_index` instead of writing out the expected type tediously?
Yes `no_index` works here

So playing around with `no_index` for a while, I suspect that the `simp_nf` linter doesn't actually pick up on that correctly. In any case, I think the fault lies more with the simp lemmas applying to objects, making things non-reducibly defeq. (That's the other main source of `erw`s I found.) But that's a problem throughout the library and not something I feel comfortable tackling here.
I think `simp; rfl` is considered potentially unstable?

```suggestion
    erw [LinearEquiv.symm_apply_apply, this]
    simp only [LinearMap.zero_apply, ChainComplex.linearYonedaObj_X, linearYoneda_obj_obj_carrier,
      map_zero, Pi.zero_apply, LinearMap.zero_apply]
    rfl
```
maybe slightly better?
Should this also be `@[simp]`? If not, let's leave a comment in place explaining why.
It shouldn't be `@[simp]` because `asHom` and `hom` are reducibly defeq to the constructor and projection, respectively, so the whole thing reduces to `f = f`.
Similarly here, either `@[simp]` or explain why it's not a good idea.
I thought this would be the same issue, but actually it would be a good `@[simp]` lemma!
This is solvable by `simp`, so I don't think we should add `@[simp]` here.
I think indeed these shouldn't be `simp`, but let's say so.

The main issue was that both of them have very bad `simp` keys, because `AlgebraCat` did not feature in the keys. This caused a +1.2% linter time increase all over mathlib. I assume it is the same situation for `ModuleCat`.
But I also agree with your two points.
These are implicitly deprecated, right? Let's write something in the doc-string.

Indeed, since this notation resolves to the deprecated `asHomLeft`/`asHomRight`, we get a deprecation warning if we actually try to use the notation. I'll add the same warning to the docstring for the notation itself.

```suggestion
@[simp] lemma hom_smul (s : S) (f : M ‚ü∂ N) : (s ‚Ä¢ f).hom = s ‚Ä¢ f.hom := rfl
```
Should we just separately have `hom_injective`? Seems convenient.
This needs `simp` lemmas.
Should we separately have a `homAddEquiv`, before assuming the smul structure?
Maybe this can just be a note for later, but I guess we could generalize this with an SMulCommClass, to `M : ModuleCat S`, `N P : ModuleCat R`.

I think that would make it difficult to make all the arrows typecheck since the objects would be in different categories.

(Also I am not sure myself which scalars you want to use for `(f : M ‚Üí‚Çó[_] N ‚Üí‚Çó[_] P)`.)
Can we not write this with the categorical arrow?
Other direction?
Nice!

The goal after `simp` here is 
```
(cokernel.œÄ g).hom (g.hom ((factorThruImageSubobject f).hom l)) = 0
```
I think we should just have a simp lemma for `(cokernel.œÄ g).hom (g.hom x) = 0`, called something like `ModuleCat.Hom.cokernel_condition`.

Ideally we'd have some tactic help, e.g. like `@[elementwise]`, but for now we should just write these at the point we set up cokernels.

We might also think (by introducing a level of indirection to `ModuleCat.Hom.hom`?) about how we could write a single simp lemma that would apply `cokernel_condition` to all of its different concrete versions.
I added a TODO comment as per our discussion.

Having to write out the source and target so often doesn't seem fun. :-(

At very least we should leave some comments on the places this is necessary, reminding us to come back.

I wonder if having a variant of `asHom` here, that took as input a semilinear map (twisted by `(Spec (CommRingCat.of R)).ringCatSheaf.val.map i`), could producing something that would typecheck more easily... Not sure yet.

Something like
```
def tildeInTypeLinearMap {U V : (Opens (PrimeSpectrum.Top R))·µí·µñ} (i : U ‚ü∂ V) :
    (M.tildeInType.1.obj U) ‚Üí‚Çõ‚Çó[(Spec (CommRingCat.of R)).ringCatSheaf.val.map i] 
        (of ((Spec (.of R)).ringCatSheaf.1.obj V) (M.tildeInType.1.obj V)) :=
  { toFun := M.tildeInType.val.map i
    map_smul' := by intros; rfl
    map_add' := by intros; rfl } 

def asHomRestrictScalars {M N : Type u} {R S : Type*} [Ring R] [Ring S] (œÉ : R ‚Üí+* S)
    [AddCommGroup M] [Module R M] [AddCommGroup N] [Module S N] 
    (f : M ‚Üí‚Çõ‚Çó[œÉ] N) :
    ModuleCat.of R M ‚ü∂ (restrictScalars œÉ).obj (ModuleCat.of S N) :=
  sorry

/--
`M^~` as a sheaf of `ùí™_{Spec R}`-modules
-/
noncomputable def tilde : (Spec (CommRingCat.of R)).Modules where
  val :=
    { obj := fun U ‚Ü¶ ModuleCat.of _ (M.tildeInType.val.obj U)
      map := fun {U V} i ‚Ü¶ 
        asHomRestrictScalars ((Spec (CommRingCat.of R)).ringCatSheaf.val.map i) (tildeInTypeLinearMap M i)
      map_id := sorry
      map_comp := sorry }
  isSheaf := (TopCat.Presheaf.isSheaf_iff_isSheaf_comp (forget AddCommGrp) _ ).2
    M.tildeInType.2
```
Why is `restrictScalars` printing with a `coe` arrow?? That is really unhelpful. :-)
I went through and added a comment at each point we have to add a type hint: looks like `restrictScalars` is always involved somehow.

pullRequest.title: refactor(Algebra/Category/ModuleCat): make `ModuleCat.Hom` a structure

`+ instance {M N : ModuleCat.{v} R} : CoeFun (M ‚ü∂ N) (fun _ ‚Ü¶ M ‚Üí N)`
`+ inv_hom_apply`
`+ ofHom_apply`
`+ ofHom_comp`
`+ ofHom_hom`
`+ ofHom_id`
`+ ofHom_œÅ`
`+ ofHom‚ÇÇ`
`+ ofHom‚ÇÇ_compr‚ÇÇ`
`+ ofHom‚ÇÇ_hom‚ÇÇ`
`+ pushforward_map_app_apply'`
`+ pushforward_obj_map_apply'`
`+ toSheafify_app_apply'`
`+ œÅ_hom`
`++ hom_ext`
`++ ofHom`
`++-- of`
`- ModuleCat.asHom`
`- ModuleCat.ofHom`
`- ModuleCat.ofHom_apply`
`- coe_comp`
`- comp_def`
`- ext`
`- instance : CoeFun (obj' f M) fun _ => S ‚Üí M where coe g := g.toFun`
`- instance {M N : FGModuleCat R} : FunLike (M ‚ü∂ N) M N`
`- instance {M N : FGModuleCat R} : LinearMapClass (M ‚ü∂ N) R M N`
`- instance {M N : ModuleCat.{v} R} : AddCommGroup (M ‚ü∂ N) := LinearMap.addCommGroup`
`- instance {M N : ModuleCat.{v} R} : FunLike (M ‚ü∂ N) M N`
`- instance {M N : ModuleCat.{v} R} : LinearMapClass (M ‚ü∂ N) R M N`
`- instance {R : Type u‚ÇÅ} {S : Type u‚ÇÇ} [Ring R] [Ring S] {f : R ‚Üí+* S}`
`- ofUnique`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>Decrease in tech debt: (relative, absolute) = (5.49, 0.03)</summary>

|Current number|Change|Type|
|-:|:-:|:-|
|4981|-30|porting notes|
|202|-2|disabled simpNF lints|
|1498|-24|erw|

Current commit [f8f8363b30](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/f8f8363b30bf3426fabad9c002a2f722daafa3f8)
Reference commit [a38db992d0](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/a38db992d088e602ba99cdf94f77435bf23e9b8e)

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Overall this looks very good and a lot of proofs got cleaner! Did you run your magic `erw -> rw` tool? I could imagine there is some potential.

I hope you don't mind that I pushed some small changes to get rid of some more `erw`s.

I tried to add a test file similar to the one for `AlgebraCat`, but I am running into this:
```
import Mathlib
open CategoryTheory ModuleCat
variable (R : Type u) [CommRing R]

/-
ambiguous, possible interpretations 
  ‚Üüf : of R X ‚ü∂ of R Y
  
  ‚Üæ‚áëf : X ‚ü∂ Y
-/
example {X Y : Type v} [AddCommGroup X] [Module R X] [AddCommGroup Y] [Module R Y] (f : X ‚Üí‚Çó[R] Y)
    (x : X) : (asHom f) x = f x := by simp
```
Do you understand this?

I think the testcase fails because there is also the definition [`CategoryTheory.asHom`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/CategoryTheory/Types.html#CategoryTheory.asHom) which is `ModuleCat.asHom` but for the category of types. So we either apply `ModuleCat.asHom` and then coerce back to a function, or we coerce `f` to a function, apply `CategoryTheory.asHom` to make it a morphism, and then coerce it back to a plain function. And since both of the end results have the same types and applicability, Lean can't choose and throws an error.

> I think the testcase fails because there is also the definition [`CategoryTheory.asHom`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/CategoryTheory/Types.html#CategoryTheory.asHom) which is `ModuleCat.asHom` but for the category of types. So we either apply `ModuleCat.asHom` and then coerce back to a function, or we coerce `f` to a function, apply `CategoryTheory.asHom` to make it a morphism, and then coerce it back to a plain function. And since both of the end results have the same types and applicability, Lean can't choose and throws an error.

Ah, silly me, I didn't think of `CategoryTheory.asHom` and was not aware of the notation. Replacing the `asHom` with `ModuleCat.asHom` makes everything work.
I put the tests in 554ba6315ef, if you like them feel free to cherry-pick (or tell me to push it here).
Thank you! Feel free to push your commit directly to this branch. :)

source.title: chore: address and delete many porting notes across the library

nodes.body:
> Overall this looks very good and a lot of proofs got cleaner! Did you run your magic `erw -> rw` tool? I could imagine there is some potential.
> 
> I hope you don't mind that I pushed some small changes to get rid of some more `erw`s.

I did run it on an earlier version of the branch, let me see if anything got cleared up in the meantime.

(It should be as easy as merging the `try_this-erw` branch into the current branch, and then cherry-picking any of the warnings it produces.)
No free `erw` eliminations found on this branch, but I did find a few in other bits of Mathlib so time to make a little PR for that :D
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/698fc869-9376-4049-8627-f1c0e9b2896c) for commit 867bc8212c6d6651ab13f5153cb4748e2e73bd3d.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/bcf67c94-f0d0-45cd-bab5-2518ad8d3eff/to/698fc869-9376-4049-8627-f1c0e9b2896c) against commit 7f28d7f73f74b31f72449bb9eb240db3ca68fe38:
```diff
  Benchmark                                                    Metric         Change
  ==================================================================================
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Algebra                  instructions   227.7%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Basic                    instructions    45.8%
+ ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.ChangeOfRings            instructions   -28.9%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Differentials.Presheaf   instructions    14.3%
+ ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Presheaf                 instructions   -17.1%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Presheaf.ChangeOfRings   instructions    28.0%
+ ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Presheaf.Monoidal        instructions   -18.0%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Presheaf.Pushforward     instructions    18.2%
+ ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Presheaf.Sheafify        instructions   -12.5%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Sheaf.Colimits           instructions    61.2%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Homology.ShortComplex.ModuleCat             instructions    66.2%
- ~Mathlib.AlgebraicGeometry.Modules.Tilde                     instructions    25.4%
+ ~Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Monoidal.Internal.Module             instructions    -9.3%
- ~Mathlib.RepresentationTheory.Rep                            instructions    12.4%
```

Hmm, a very mixed result. The really big slowdowns were in files that had a lot of manual proofs replaced with automation, but still `Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Sheaf.Colimits` +61.2% with no changed lines is scary. Let me see if I can discover what is slow...

The +227% one can be safely ignored, its a 60L file with one proof. Why do we not get the nice summary with all the instruction increases starting from 10^9? Does this mean, all of the changes are below that threshold? If yes, I think everything is fine.

`Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Sheaf.Colimits` is also a one-proof file. If I can trust `set_option trace.profiler true` somewhat, then it looks like elaboration of that proof takes slightly less than `50%` longer, and kernel typechecking twice as long. But there is no obvious change in the steps taken to get there, just a bit of slowdown at every level...

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#19705~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ü§ñ). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/1807ed17-3561-4775-aac8-55b11db574ad) for commit f8f8363b30bf3426fabad9c002a2f722daafa3f8.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/376caf18-3015-4b16-80e7-6763a47746fd/to/1807ed17-3561-4775-aac8-55b11db574ad) against commit a38db992d088e602ba99cdf94f77435bf23e9b8e:
```diff
  Benchmark                                                    Metric         Change
  ==================================================================================
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Algebra                  instructions   227.1%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Basic                    instructions    46.7%
+ ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.ChangeOfRings            instructions   -30.3%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Differentials.Presheaf   instructions    15.2%
+ ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Presheaf                 instructions   -16.9%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Presheaf.ChangeOfRings   instructions    28.3%
+ ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Presheaf.Monoidal        instructions   -16.7%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Presheaf.Pushforward     instructions    19.1%
+ ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Presheaf.Sheafify        instructions   -13.4%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Sheaf.Colimits           instructions    61.8%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Homology.ShortComplex.ModuleCat             instructions    71.3%
- ~Mathlib.AlgebraicGeometry.Modules.Tilde                     instructions    24.1%
- ~Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Linear.Yoneda                        instructions    19.8%
+ ~Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Monoidal.Internal.Module             instructions    -9.2%
- ~Mathlib.RepresentationTheory.Rep                            instructions    12.1%
```
